passages.text: Cinda AMC, Meituan, CNGO, Tai Oil
Cinda AMC - Swings to pre- tax loss
Meituan - Balance sheet deterioration + potential rating downgrade = move to Neutral
CNOOC - Weak 1H25 results but strong financial profile
Thai Oil - About \(\) 200\(m of tender offer

Interim results for China Cinda Asset Management (bond ticker: CCAMCL) reflected continued pressure on the distressed asset management (DAM) business due weak revenue generation and elevated impairments. On the other hand, we believe state backing for the company remains intact and underpins the investment story. We reiterate a Neutral recommendation on the company, including its \(5.5\%\) 2030 senior bonds, which are offered at \(z + 108bp\) (SOT+71bp, \(4.4\%\) \(\) 104.5\(). We see better value in other parts of the China financials space, including among bonds such as those issued by CDB Leasing entities (please see yesterday's Asia Credit Roundup for more details). On the other hand, we expect government support to limit underperformance. Please see the May EM Corporate Coverage Report for risks to our recommendation on CCAMCL.

Profit before tax swung to a net loss of - RMB2.6 billion, compared to + RMB2.9 billion in 1H'24, although net profit after tax came in at RMB905 million. A large driver was a \(65\%\) y/y increase in credit impairment losses to RMB7.9 billion. The company also recognized an RMB1.6 billion impairment on properties held for sale by Cinda Real Estate; this compares with a much more modest impairment of only RMB42 million in the year- ago period. The DAM business lost RMB6.2 billion on a pre- tax basis, compared to positive earnings of RMB749 million in 1H'24. The disappointing pre- tax figure for 1H'25 occurred despite stable y/y revenues as asset impairment provisions and the loss from unrealized fair value changes totaling - RMB14.8 billion, an RMB5.0 billion y/y increase. The Financial Services business continues to be the main profitability driver, contributing RMB3.5 billion in pre- tax profits, including RMB2.0 billion from Nanyang Commercial Bank, the largest portion of the Financial Services business. Capital ratios declined roughly 200bp in general, with the Core Tier 1 ratio falling from 16.07% in December to 9.66%; the total Capital Adequacy Ratio moved from 16.75% to 14.69%. The absolute amount of capital declined very slightly, while risk- weighted assets increased 13%. (Matt)

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

Meituan's 2Q25 net profit dropped \(90\%\) yoy as it ramped up consumer subsidies to fend off Alibaba and JD from a fierce food delivery competition. We expect the company to turn lossmaking along with a deterioration in credit profile in 2025E/26E, as a result of (1) potential market share loss to Alibaba due to the latter's strong commitment to expand in the China food delivery/quick commerce market, and (2) an extended offering of aggressive subsidies. MEITUA is currently rated Baa1/A- BBB+ (M/S/F) with a stable/stable/positive outlook, and we see rating downgrade risks if its competitive position is structurally weakened, or if leverage ratios sustain at elevated levels. We move MEITUA \(29\%\) (4.5% ytm, \(SOT + 78\) ) and \(30\%\) (4.5% ytm, \(SOT + 84\) ) from OW to Neutral, as we expect credit spreads to widen near term to reflect a cloudier financial outlook and potential downgrade by rating agencies. In the single- A TMT space, we prefer TENCNT \(38s\) (SOT+62) and \(50s\) (SOT+52), due to (1) Tencent's disciplined investment strategy and solid financial outlook, and (2) the credits' relatively wide pick- up vs the front end. Please see the full report for details. (Alvin)

CNOOC reported weak 1H25 results, as revenue/EBITDA/net profit decreased \(8\% /6\% /13\%\) yoy, due to mixed impacts from the ongoing weakness in oil prices and its stringent cost control. The exploration and production (E&P) segment's revenue/net profit decreased \(6\% /11\%\) yoy in 1H. Despite facing volatile oil prices and weak demand, CNOOC's 1H25 net production of oil & gas increased by \(6\%\) yoy. Notably, the company achieved a remarkable \(12\%\) increase in natural gas production.

Recall that CNOOC announced to exit its oil & gas business in the US Gulf of Mexico in December 2024, leading to a cut in FY25- 26 production guidance by \(3 - 4\%\) in January 2025. Accordingly, CNOOC reported a book value of the GoM assets held for sale at Rmb7.24bn as of end- 2024 (vs. the last- reported book value of US \(3.24bn\) (Rmb20.9bn) as of 1H21). In terms of its overseas strategy, on August 8, CNOOC announced that Yellowtail Project in Stabroek block off the coast of Guyana has commenced production ahead of schedule. The Yellowtail Project has a production capacity of 250,000 barrels per day, bringing the total Stabroek Block production capacity to 900,000 barrels per day, in which CNOOC holds a \(25\%\) share.

Despite weak earnings, CNOOC reported a strong balance sheet, with net cash jumping \(70\%\) hoh to Rmb184bn, due to a \(16\%\) increase in cash and a \(21\%\) decrease in total debt in 1H. Its net cash to equity ratio increased from \(14\%\) (2024YE) to \(23\%\) . Additionally, CNOOC disclosed that one of its wholly owned subsidiaries, CNOOC Petroleum North America ULC (CPNA) repurchased two bonds due in 2032 and 2037, respectively, totaling US \(4.6mn face value, backed by its strong financial position. (Emma/Alvin)

Thai Oil has announced a cash tender offer for four of its bond tranches, as follows: 1) TOPTB \(4.875\%\) 43s (amount outstanding \(\) 138m\(and\) \ \(262m\) across two tranches): Up to \(\sim\) 60m national tender cap (split as \(\) 28m\(and\) \ \(32m\) for two tranches) at early tender consideration of \(\) 86.875\(G + 141bps, 6.11\%\) ytw); 2) TOPTB \(5.375\%\) 48s ( \(\) 480m\(): Up to\) \ \(90m\) national tender cap at early tender consideration of \(\) 91.625\(G + 118bps, 6.05\%\) ytw); and 3) TOPTB \(3.75\%\) 50s ( \(\) 480m\(: Up to\) \ \(50m\) national tender cap at early tender consideration of \(\) 71.5\(G + 109bps, 5.96\%\) ytw)

Cumulatively, this will account for \(\sim\) 200m of buyback in notional amount (assuming tender cap or maximum acceptance amount is reached and accepted by the company). This would bring the total amount of buybacks done by Thai Oil in 2025 to \(\sim\) 533m in notional terms. We estimate this to have led to deleveraging (net debt basis) of \(\sim\) 900- 100m for Thai Oil, given the buybacks have largely been done at substantially below par levels.

**While we consider the tender to be reasonable, we do believe based on spreads at the tender consideration, Thai Oil's tender offer on TOPTB 43s looks the least attractive while that for the TOPTB 50s looks the most attractive.** Overall, we believe the tender offer provides additional support to the technical for the USD bonds. **On the credit, we turned positive earlier this month with an OW recommendation across the TOPTB curve and prefer TOPTB over PTTGC (OW '31s and '32s, N '51s).** We do not view TOPTB as a fallen angel candidate now, with Moody's likely to allow Thai Oil time to complete asset sales, hybrid debt issuances and other deleveraging measures to maintain the ratings at Baa3. Please refer to our recent note ("PTT Complex: No mood to downgrade", 12 Aug 25) for details and key risks to our recommendations. (Love)

J.P. Morgan uses a bond- level rating system that incorporates valuations (relative value) and our fundamental view on the security. Our fundamental credit view of an issuer is based on the company's underlying credit trends, overall creditworthiness and our opinion on whether the issuer will be able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable. We analyze, among other things, the company's cash flow capacity and trends and standard credit ratios, such as gross and net leverage, interest coverage and liquidity ratios. We also analyze profitability, capitalization and asset quality, among other variables, when assessing financials. Analysts also rate the issuer, based on the rating of the benchmark or representative security. Unless we specify a different recommendation for the company's individual securities, an issuer recommendation applies to all of the bonds at the same level of the issuer's capital structure. We may also rate certain loans and preferred securities, as applicable. This report also sets out within it the material underlying assumptions used. We use the following ratings for bonds (issues), issuers, loans, and preferred securities: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark). J.P. Morgan Emerging Markets Sovereign Research uses Marketweight, which is equivalent to Neutral. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this particular security or issuer because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. For CDS, we use the following rating system: Long Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to exceed the relevant index, sector or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to match the relevant index, sector or benchmark); and Short Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector or benchmark).
